title: Relates to establishing the crime of sexual abuse of authority
summary: Relates to establishing the crime of sexual abuse of authority, pertaining to sexual conduct between a teacher and a student.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2118

TITLE OF BILL:

An act
to amend the penal law, in relation to establishing the crime of sexual
abuse of authority

PURPOSE:

This bill relates to establishing the crime of sexual abuse of
authority.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:

Section 1 amends the penal law by adding a new section 130.97. A
person is guilty of sexual abuse of authority when he or she engages
in sexual conduct with another who is not the spouse of the offender
when the offender is a teacher, administrator, coach or other person
in authority employed by or serving in an elementary or secondary
school, or a college or university.

Sexual abuse of authority shall be a class A misdemeanor.

JUSTIFICATION:

This bill makes it illegal for school employees to have sex with
students, regardless of age or consent. Under current law, no
criminal charges can be brought against offending employees because
the students are not minors. Schools Chancellor Joel Klein
specifically requested that this legislation be introduced after two
Manhattan high school faculty members engaged in consensual sexual
relations with 18 year old students.

Under the provisions of this legislation, it will be easier for school
districts to dismiss employees engaging in questionable, immoral
activity.

Connecticut and Ohio have enacted similar measures.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:

New bill.

EFFECTIVE DATE:

This act shall take effect on the first of November next succeeding
the date on which it shall become law.
